title: How to Make Cheese and Bacon Puffs

steps.headline: Wash your hands, tie back long hair, wipe down any surfaces that you will use making the puffs and gather the ingredients and equipment.
Grate the cheese into medium sized gratings.
Put the frying pan on the hob and switch the hob onto the highest setting.
steps.description: Leave the pan for 2 - 4 minutes to heat.

steps.headline: Add the chopped bacon to the pan and cook until the bacon is a darker pink, the fat has shrunk and it is clearly cooked, stirring occasionally with the wooden spoon to prevent the bacon from burning.
Turn the hob down to a mid-to-low setting, and add a third of the cheese, stirring with the bacon immediately to prevent burning or sticking to the pan.
Repeat with the remaining cheese until it is all in the pan and the cheese and bacon is combined, with the cheese all melted.
Pour the cheese and bacon into the small bowl, and leave for 1 minute to cool down somewhat.
steps.description: During this time, turn off the hob and soak the frying pan to prevent any food from sticking to it or staining it.

steps.headline: Add the beaten egg to the cheese and bacon while it is still warm and stir thoroughly so the egg is combined.
steps.description: The remaining heat of the cheese and bacon will somewhat cook the egg, while the egg will help to combine the ingredients.

steps.headline: Put the egg, cheese and bacon mixture into the fridge.
In the large bowl, put half of your lard and all your flour, and then rub the lard into the flour until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs with some flour still present.
Using the pallet knife, stir in a tablespoon of water at a time until the mixture comes easily as a slightly sticky dough.
steps.description: It should be pale and easily workable.

steps.headline: Lightly flour a large, flat surface with the flour dredger, with the rolling pin.
steps.description: Do not over-flour as this can change the fat:flour ratio of the pastry.

steps.headline: Place the dough ball onto the flour and roll out until it is a large rectangle of about half a centimetre thick.
steps.description: Be careful to continuously turn the pastry or it may stick to the surface, and ensure you re-flour the surface when necessary.

steps.headline: Across two-thirds of the pastry, place about a third of the butter and a third of the remaining lard or white fat evenly across it, before folding up the bottom half of the pastry over the other pastry and folding down the upper part of the pastry.
Refrigerate the pastry for five to ten minutes to ensure the fat doesn't melt.
steps.description: If the fat melts, it will lessen the leavening process.

steps.headline: Remove the pastry from the fridge, reflour the surface and firmly pat across the top of the pastry to compress it slightly, before repeating steps 13 - 15 until all the fat is gone.

Roll out the pastry, which now has all the fat rolled into layers inside it, to a large square or rectangle just under half a centimetre thick, before cutting into even squares about two inches on all sides.
Place the oven on at 180 °C (356 °F).
Remove the cheese, bacon and egg mixture from the fridge - it should now be solid, but easy to separate.

To the centre of each square, add a teaspoon of the cheese, bacon and egg mixture, before folding each corner up to the middle of the square and squeezing their edges together to create a small pastry parcel.
Lightly grease a baking tray before placing the squares on it, ensuring there is a gap of about an inch between every point of every puff.
steps.description: You may need to use two or three trays.

steps.headline: Place the puffs in the oven for 20 - 25 minutes or until golden brown with the mixture inside bubbling and possibly oozing out of the pastry.
Finished.
